45-2093.d: Attend to live farm, ranch, open range or aquacultural animals that may include cattle, sheep, swine, goats, horses and other equines, poultry, rabbits, finfish, shellfish, and bees. Attend to animals produced for animal products, such as meat, fur, skins, feathers, eggs, milk, and honey. Duties may include feeding, watering, herding, grazing, milking, castrating, branding, de-beaking, weighing, catching, and loading animals. May maintain records on animals; examine animals to detect diseases and injuries; assist in birth deliveries; and administer medications, vaccinations, or insecticides as appropriate. May clean and maintain animal housing areas. Includes workers who shear wool from sheep and collect eggs in hatcheries.
45-2093.e: Cattle Brander, Sheep Shearer, Shrimp Pond Laborer

45-2099.d: All agricultural workers not listed separately.

45-3031.d: Hunt, trap, catch, or gather wild animals or aquatic animals and plants. May use nets, traps, or other equipment. May haul catch onto ship or other vessel. Aquacultural laborers who work on fish farms are included in "Farmworkers, Farm, Ranch, and Aquacultural Animals" (45-2093).
45-3031.e: Bird Trapper, Deer Hunter, Predatory Animal Trapper, Seaweed Harvester, Wild Oyster Harvester

45-4011.d: Under supervision, perform manual labor necessary to develop, maintain, or protect areas such as forests, forested areas, woodlands, wetlands, and rangelands through such activities as raising and transporting seedlings; combating insects, pests, and diseases harmful to plant life; and building structures to control water, erosion, and leaching of soil. Includes forester aides, seedling pullers, tree planters, and gatherers of nontimber forestry products such as pine straw.
45-4011.e: Forestry Laborer, Rangelands Conservation Laborer, Reforestation Worker, Wetlands Conservation Laborer

45-4021.d: Use axes or chainsaws to fell trees using knowledge of tree characteristics and cutting techniques to control direction of fall and minimize tree damage.

45-4022.d: Drive logging tractor or wheeled vehicle equipped with one or more accessories, such as bulldozer blade, frontal shear, grapple, logging arch, cable winches, hoisting rack, or crane boom, to fell tree; to skid, load, unload, or stack logs; or to pull stumps or clear brush. Includes operating stand-alone logging machines, such as log chippers. Logging truck drivers are included in "Heavy and Tractor-Trailer Truck Drivers" (53-3032).
45-4022.e: Grapple Skidder Operator, Log Hauler, Logging Tractor Operator, Lumber Stacker Operator

45-4023.d: Grade logs or estimate the marketable content or value of logs or pulpwood in sorting yards, millpond, log deck, or similar locations. Inspect logs for defects or measure logs to determine volume.
45-4023.e: Log Check Scaler, Timber Estimator, Veneer Grader

45-4029.d: All logging workers not listed separately.
45-4029.e: Log Roper, Rigging Slinger, Timber Hand

47-1011.t: First-Line Supervisors of Construction Trades and Extraction Workers
47-1011.d: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of construction or extraction workers.
47-1011.e: Carpenter Supervisor, Quarry Boss, Rig Supervisor, Solar Panel Installation Supervisor

47-2011.d: Construct, assemble, maintain, and repair stationary steam boilers and boiler house auxiliaries. Align structures or plate sections to assemble boiler frame tanks or vats, following blueprints. Work involves use of hand and power tools, plumb bobs, levels, wedges, dogs, or turnbuckles. Assist in testing assembled vessels. Direct cleaning of boilers and boiler furnaces. Inspect and repair boiler fittings, such as safety valves, regulators, automatic-control mechanisms, water columns, and auxiliary machines.
47-2011.e: Boiler Installer, Boiler Mechanic, Boiler Tester

47-2021.d: Lay and bind building materials, such as brick, structural tile, concrete block, cinder block, glass block, and terra-cotta block, with mortar and other substances, to construct or repair walls, partitions, arches, sewers, and other structures. Installers of mortarless segmental concrete masonry wall units are classified in "Landscaping and Groundskeeping Workers" (37-3011).
47-2021.e: Adobe Layer, Brick Chimney Builder, Refractory Bricklayer

47-2022.d: Build stone structures, such as piers, walls, and abutments. Lay walks, curbstones, or special types of masonry for vats, tanks, and floors.
47-2022.e: Curbstone Setter, Granite Setter, Monument Mason

47-2031.d: Construct, erect, install, or repair structures and fixtures made of wood and comparable materials, such as concrete forms; building frameworks, including partitions, joists, studding, and rafters; and wood stairways, window and door frames, and hardwood floors. May also install cabinets, siding, drywall, and batt or roll insulation. Includes brattice builders who build doors or brattices (ventilation walls or partitions) in underground passageways.
47-2031.e: Building Carpenter, Custom Wood Stair Builder, Wood Floor Layer

47-2041.d: Lay and install carpet from rolls or blocks on floors. Install padding and trim flooring materials.

47-2042.t: Floor Layers, Except Carpet, Wood, and Hard Tiles
47-2042.d: Apply blocks, strips, or sheets of shock-absorbing, sound-deadening, or decorative coverings to floors.
47-2042.e: Composition Floor Layer, Cork Floor Installer, Linoleum Installer, Shock-Absorption Floor Layer

47-2043.d: Scrape and sand wooden floors to smooth surfaces using floor scraper and floor sanding machine, and apply coats of finish.
47-2043.e: Floor Sanding Machine Operator, Floor Scraper, Hardwood Finisher

47-2044.d: Apply hard tile, stone, and comparable materials to walls, floors, ceilings, countertops, and roof decks.
47-2044.e: Ceramic Tile Installer, Hard Tile Setter, Marble Ceiling Installer, Parquet Floor Layer

47-2051.d: Smooth and finish surfaces of poured concrete, such as floors, walks, sidewalks, roads, or curbs using a variety of hand and power tools. Align forms for sidewalks, curbs, or gutters; patch voids; and use saws to cut expansion joints. Installers of mortarless segmental concrete masonry wall units are classified in "Landscaping and Groundskeeping Workers" (37-3011).
47-2051.e: Cement Patcher, Concrete Floor Installer, Concrete Swimming Pool Installer

47-2053.d: Apply a mixture of cement, sand, pigment, or marble chips to floors, stairways, and cabinet fixtures to fashion durable and decorative surfaces.
47-2053.e: Onyx-Chip Terrazzo Worker, Terrazzo Grinder, Terrazzo Setter

47-2061.d: Perform tasks involving physical labor at construction sites. May operate hand and power tools of all types: air hammers, earth tampers, cement mixers, small mechanical hoists, surveying and measuring equipment, and a variety of other equipment and instruments. May clean and prepare sites, dig trenches, set braces to support the sides of excavations, erect scaffolding, and clean up rubble, debris, and other waste materials. May assist other craft workers. Construction laborers who primarily assist a particular craft worker are classified under "Helpers, Construction Trades" (47-3010).
47-2061.e: Air Hammer Operator, Construction Craft Laborer, Construction Trench Digger

47-2071.t: Paving, Surfacing, and Tamping Equipment Operators
47-2071.d: Operate equipment used for applying concrete, asphalt, or other materials to road beds, parking lots, or airport runways and taxiways or for tamping gravel, dirt, or other materials. Includes concrete and asphalt paving machine operators, form tampers, tamping machine operators, and stone spreader operators.

47-2072.d: Operate pile drivers mounted on skids, barges, crawler treads, or locomotive cranes to drive pilings for retaining walls, bulkheads, and foundations of structures such as buildings, bridges, and piers.
47-2072.e: Hydraulic Pile Hammer Operator, Vibratory Pile Driver

47-2073.t: Operating Engineers and Other Construction Equipment Operators
47-2073.d: Operate one or several types of power construction equipment, such as motor graders, bulldozers, scrapers, compressors, pumps, derricks, shovels, tractors, or front-end loaders to excavate, move, and grade earth, erect structures, or pour concrete or other hard surface pavement. May repair and maintain equipment in addition to other duties.
47-2073.e: Construction Bulldozer Operator, Road Grader, Steam Shovel Operator

47-2081.d: Apply plasterboard or other wallboard to ceilings or interior walls of buildings. Apply or mount acoustical tiles or blocks, strips, or sheets of shock-absorbing materials to ceilings and walls of buildings to reduce or reflect sound. Materials may be of decorative quality. Includes lathers who fasten wooden, metal, or rockboard lath to walls, ceilings, or partitions of buildings to provide support base for plaster, fireproofing, or acoustical material.
47-2081.e: Acoustical Ceiling Installer, Drywall Finisher, Sheet Rock Hanger

47-2082.d: Seal joints between plasterboard or other wallboard to prepare wall surface for painting or papering.
47-2082.e: Drywall Taper, Sheet Rock Taper, Wall Taper

47-2111.d: Install, maintain, and repair electrical wiring, equipment, and fixtures. Ensure that work is in accordance with relevant codes. May install or service street lights, intercom systems, or electrical control systems.
47-2111.e: Electrical Sign Wirer, Master Electrician, Solar Photovoltaic Electrician

47-2121.d: Install glass in windows, skylights, store fronts, and display cases, or on surfaces, such as building fronts, interior walls, ceilings, and tabletops.
47-2121.e: Plate Glass Installer, Stained Glass Joiner

47-2131.t: Insulation Workers, Floor, Ceiling, and Wall
47-2131.d: Line and cover structures with insulating materials. May work with batt, roll, or blown insulation materials.
47-2131.e: Ceiling Insulation Blower, Composition Weatherboard Installer, Interior Surface Insulation Worker

47-2132.d: Apply insulating materials to pipes or ductwork, or other mechanical systems in order to help control and maintain temperature.
47-2132.e: Boiler Coverer, Pipe Coverer, Pipe Insulator

47-2141.d: Paint walls, equipment, buildings, bridges, and other structural surfaces, using brushes, rollers, and spray guns. May remove old paint to prepare surface prior to painting. May mix colors or oils to obtain desired color or consistency.
47-2141.e: Bridge Painter, House Painter, Traffic Line Painter

47-2142.d: Cover interior walls or ceilings of rooms with decorative wallpaper or fabric, or attach advertising posters on surfaces such as walls and billboards. May remove old materials or prepare surfaces to be papered.
47-2142.e: Billboard Poster, Wall Covering Installer, Wallpaperer

47-2151.d: Lay pipe for storm or sanitation sewers, drains, and water mains. Perform any combination of the following tasks: grade trenches or culverts, position pipe, or seal joints.
47-2151.e: Cast-Iron Drain Pipe Layer, Trench Pipe Layer, Water Main Pipe Layer

47-2152.d: Assemble, install, alter, and repair pipelines or pipe systems that carry water, steam, air, or other liquids or gases. May install heating and cooling equipment and mechanical control systems. Includes sprinkler fitters.
47-2152.e: Fire Sprinkler Installer, Solar Thermal Installer, Sprinkler Fitter

47-2161.d: Apply interior or exterior plaster, cement, stucco, or similar materials. May also set ornamental plaster.
47-2161.e: Ornamental Plasterer, Stucco Worker, Swimming Pool Plasterer

47-2171.d: Position and secure steel bars or mesh in concrete forms in order to reinforce concrete. Use a variety of fasteners, rod-bending machines, blowtorches, and hand tools. Includes rod busters.
47-2171.e: Post Tensioning Ironworker, Steel Rod Buster

47-2181.d: Cover roofs of structures with shingles, slate, asphalt, aluminum, wood, or related materials. May spray roofs, sidings, and walls with material to bind, seal, insulate, or soundproof sections of structures.
47-2181.e: Hot Tar Roofer, Shingles Roofer, Terra Cotta Roofer

47-2211.d: Fabricate, assemble, install, and repair sheet metal products and equipment, such as ducts, control boxes, drainpipes, and furnace casings. Work may involve any of the following: setting up and operating fabricating machines to cut, bend, and straighten sheet metal; shaping metal over anvils, blocks, or forms using hammer; operating soldering and welding equipment to join sheet metal parts; or inspecting, assembling, and smoothing seams and joints of burred surfaces. Includes sheet metal duct installers who install prefabricated sheet metal ducts used for heating, air conditioning, or other purposes.
47-2211.e: Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) Sheet Metal Installer, Sheet Metal Former, Tinsmith

47-2221.d: Raise, place, and unite iron or steel girders, columns, and other structural members to form completed structures or structural frameworks. May erect metal storage tanks and assemble prefabricated metal buildings.
47-2221.e: Bridge Ironworker, Precast Concrete Ironworker, Wind Turbine Erector

47-2231.d: Assemble, install, or maintain solar photovoltaic (PV) systems on roofs or other structures in compliance with site assessment and schematics. May include measuring, cutting, assembling, and bolting structural framing and solar modules. May perform minor electrical work such as current checks.
47-2231.e: Photovoltaic (PV) Installation Technician, Solar PV Installer

47-3011.t: Helpers--Brickmasons, Blockmasons, Stonemasons, and Tile and Marble Setters
47-3011.d: Help brickmasons, blockmasons, stonemasons, or tile and marble setters by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist brickmasons, blockmasons, and stonemasons or tile and marble setters are classified under "Construction Laborers" (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).
47-3011.e: Brick Carrier, Brick Washer, Refractory Tile Helper

47-3012.d: Help carpenters by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist carpenters are classified under "Construction Laborers" (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).
47-3012.e: Carpenter Assistant, Hardwood Floor Installation Helper

47-3013.d: Help electricians by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist electricians are classified under "Construction Laborers" (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).
47-3013.e: Marine Electrician Helper, Stage Electrician Helper

47-3014.t: Helpers--Painters, Paperhangers, Plasterers, and Stucco Masons
47-3014.d: Help painters, paperhangers, plasterers, or stucco masons by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist painters, paperhangers, plasterers, or stucco masons are classified under "Construction Laborers" (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).
47-3014.e: Bridge Painter Helper, Dry Plasterer Helper, Wallpaperer Helper

47-3015.d: Help plumbers, pipefitters, steamfitters, or pipelayers by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist plumbers, pipefitters, steamfitters, or pipelayers are classified under "Construction Laborers" (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).
47-3015.e: Industrial Gas Fitter Helper, Marine Pipefitter Helper, Plumber Assistant, Water Main Installer Helper

47-3016.d: Help roofers by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist roofers are classified under "Construction Laborers" (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).
47-3016.e: Hot Tar Roofer Helper, Shingles Roofer Helper, Slate Roofer Helper, Terra Cotta Roofer Helper

47-3019.d: All construction trades helpers not listed separately.
47-3019.e: Cellulose Insulation Helper, Drywall Hanger Helper, Rod Buster Helper, Terrazzo Finisher Helper

47-4011.d: Inspect structures using engineering skills to determine structural soundness and compliance with specifications, building codes, and other regulations. Inspections may be general in nature or may be limited to a specific area, such as electrical systems or plumbing.
47-4011.e: Electrical Inspector, Elevator Inspector, Highway Inspector, Home Inspector

47-4021.t: Elevator and Escalator Installers and Repairers
47-4021.d: Assemble, install, repair, or maintain electric or hydraulic freight or passenger elevators, escalators, or dumbwaiters.
47-4021.e: Elevator Mechanic, Escalator Installer, Hydraulic Elevator Constructor

47-4031.d: Erect and repair fences and fence gates, using hand and power tools.
47-4031.e: Wire Fence Builder, Wood Fence Installer

47-4041.d: Identify, remove, pack, transport, or dispose of hazardous materials, including asbestos, lead-based paint, waste oil, fuel, transmission fluid, radioactive materials, or contaminated soil. Specialized training and certification in hazardous materials handling or a confined entry permit are generally required. May operate earth-moving equipment or trucks.
47-4041.e: Asbestos Abatement Worker, Decontamination Worker, Irradiated Fuel Handler

47-4051.d: Maintain highways, municipal and rural roads, airport runways, and rights-of-way. Duties include patching broken or eroded pavement and repairing guard rails, highway markers, and snow fences. May also mow or clear brush from along road, or plow snow from roadway.

47-4061.t: Rail-Track Laying and Maintenance Equipment Operators
47-4061.d: Lay, repair, and maintain track for standard or narrow-gauge railroad equipment used in regular railroad service or in plant yards, quarries, sand and gravel pits, and mines. Includes ballast cleaning machine operators and railroad bed tamping machine operators.
47-4061.e: Rail Maintenance Worker, Track Repairer, Track Surfacing Machine Operator

47-4071.t: Septic Tank Servicers and Sewer Pipe Cleaners
47-4071.d: Clean and repair septic tanks, sewer lines, or drains. May patch walls and partitions of tank, replace damaged drain tile, or repair breaks in underground piping.
47-4071.e: Electric Sewer Cleaning Machine Operator, Septic Tank Cleaner, Sewage Screen Operator

47-4091.d: Lay out, cut, and place segmental paving units. Includes installers of bedding and restraining materials for the paving units.
47-4091.e: Concrete Pavement Installer, Paving Stone Installer

47-4099.t: Construction and Related Workers, All Other
47-4099.d: All construction and related workers not listed separately.

47-5011.d: Rig derrick equipment and operate pumps to circulate mud or fluid through drill hole.
47-5011.e: Fracturing Derrick Operator, Rotary Derrick Operator, Well Service Derrick Worker

47-5012.t: Rotary Drill Operators, Oil and Gas
47-5012.d: Set up or operate a variety of drills to remove underground oil and gas, or remove core samples for testing during oil and gas exploration.
47-5012.e: Fracturing Rotary Drill Operator, Oil Well Cable Tool Operator, Oil Well Driller

47-5013.t: Service Unit Operators, Oil and Gas
47-5013.d: Operate equipment to increase oil flow from producing wells or to remove stuck pipe, casing, tools, or other obstructions from drilling wells. Includes fishing-tool technicians.

47-5022.t: Excavating and Loading Machine and Dragline Operators, Surface Mining
47-5022.d: Operate or tend machinery at surface mining site, equipped with scoops, shovels, or buckets to excavate and load loose materials.
47-5022.e: Mining Bulldozer Operator, Mining Shovel Operator

47-5023.t: Earth Drillers, Except Oil and Gas
47-5023.d: Operate a variety of drills such as rotary, churn, and pneumatic to tap subsurface water and salt deposits, to remove core samples during mineral exploration or soil testing, and to facilitate the use of explosives in mining or construction. Includes horizontal and earth boring machine operators.
47-5023.e: Blast Hole Driller, Churn Driller, Earth Auger Operator

47-5032.t: Explosives Workers, Ordnance Handling Experts, and Blasters
47-5032.d: Place and detonate explosives to demolish structures or to loosen, remove, or displace earth, rock, or other materials. May perform specialized handling, storage, and accounting procedures.
47-5032.e: Blast Setter, Dynamiter, Explosive Technician, Mining Powder Crew Worker

47-5041.d: Operate self-propelled mining machines that rip coal, metal and nonmetal ores, rock, stone, or sand from the mine face and load it onto conveyors, shuttle cars, or trucks in a continuous operation.
47-5041.e: Continuous Mining Machine Lode Miner, Continuous Mining Machine Miner, Self-Propelled Mining Machine Operator

47-5043.d: Operate machinery to install roof support bolts in underground mine.
47-5043.e: Roof Bolting Coal Miner, Underground Bolting Machine Operator, Underground Roof Bolter

47-5044.t: Loading and Moving Machine Operators, Underground Mining
47-5044.d: Operate underground loading or moving machine to load or move coal, ore, or rock using shuttle or mine car or conveyors. Equipment may include power shovels, hoisting engines equipped with cable-drawn scraper or scoop, or machines equipped with gathering arms and conveyor.
47-5044.e: Coal Hauler Operator, Coke Loader, Mine Shuttle Car Operator, Mobile Bridge Conveyor Operator

47-5049.t: Underground Mining Machine Operators, All Other
47-5049.d: All underground mining machine operators not listed separately.
47-5049.e: Long Wall Operator, Long Wall Shearer, Rock Dust Sprayer, Underground Jumbo Driller

47-5051.d: Separate blocks of rough dimension stone from quarry mass using jackhammers, wedges, or chop saws.
47-5051.e: Quarry Chop Saw Operator, Quarry Plug and Feather Driller, Sandstone Splitter

47-5071.d: Assemble or repair oil field equipment using hand and power tools. Perform other tasks as needed.
47-5071.e: Gas Floorhand, Oil Field Roustabout, Oil Rig Roughneck

47-5081.d: Help extraction craft workers, such as earth drillers, blasters and explosives workers, derrick operators, and mining machine operators, by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include supplying equipment or cleaning work area. Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).
47-5081.e: Blaster Helper, Mining Helper, Roof Bolter Helper

47-5099.d: All extraction workers not listed separately.
47-5099.e: Mine Milling Worker, Mine Tailings Worker

49-1011.t: First-Line Supervisors of Mechanics, Installers, and Repairers
49-1011.d: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of mechanics, installers, and repairers. May also advise customers on recommended services.
49-1011.e: Automobile Body Repair Supervisor, Fleet Maintenance Supervisor, Railroad Car Repair Supervisor

49-2011.t: Computer, Automated Teller, and Office Machine Repairers
49-2011.d: Repair, maintain, or install computers, word processing systems, automated teller machines, and electronic office machines, such as duplicating and fax machines.
49-2011.e: ATM Servicer, Cash Register Servicer, Data Processing Equipment Repairer

49-2021.t: Radio, Cellular, and Tower Equipment Installers and Repairers
49-2021.d: Repair, install, or maintain mobile or stationary radio transmitting, broadcasting, and receiving equipment, and two-way radio communications systems used in cellular telecommunications, mobile broadband, ship-to-shore, aircraft-to-ground communications, and radio equipment in service and emergency vehicles. May test and analyze network coverage.
49-2021.e: Radio Frequency Technician, Radio Mechanic, Two-Way Radio Technician

49-2022.t: Telecommunications Equipment Installers and Repairers, Except Line Installers
49-2022.d: Install, set up, rearrange, or remove switching, distribution, routing, and dialing equipment used in central offices or headends. Service or repair telephone, cable television, Internet, and other communications equipment on customers' property. May install communications equipment or communications wiring in buildings.
49-2022.e: Fiber Optic Central Office Installer, Private Branch Exchange (PBX ) Installer and Repairer

49-2091.d: Install, inspect, test, adjust, or repair avionics equipment, such as radar, radio, navigation, and missile control systems in aircraft or space vehicles.
49-2091.e: Aircraft Electrician, Aircraft Instrument Mechanic, Automatic Pilot Mechanic

49-2092.t: Electric Motor, Power Tool, and Related Repairers
49-2092.d: Repair, maintain, or install electric motors, wiring, or switches.

49-2093.t: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers, Transportation Equipment
49-2093.d: Install, adjust, or maintain mobile electronics communication equipment, including sound, sonar, security, navigation, and surveillance systems on trains, watercraft, or other mobile equipment.

49-2094.t: Electrical and Electronics Repairers, Commercial and Industrial Equipment
49-2094.d: Repair, test, adjust, or install electronic equipment, such as industrial controls, transmitters, and antennas.
49-2094.e: Industrial Robotics Mechanic, Missile Pad Mechanic, Public Address System Mechanic

49-2095.t: Electrical and Electronics Repairers, Powerhouse, Substation, and Relay
49-2095.d: Inspect, test, repair, or maintain electrical equipment in generating stations, substations, and in-service relays.
49-2095.e: Power Transformer Repairer, Powerhouse Electrician, Relay Technician

49-2096.t: Electronic Equipment Installers and Repairers, Motor Vehicles
49-2096.d: Install, diagnose, or repair communications, sound, security, or navigation equipment in motor vehicles.
49-2096.e: Automotive Electrician, Car Alarm Installer, Car Stereo Installer, GPS Car Navigation Installer

49-2097.d: Install, repair, or adjust audio or television receivers, stereo systems, camcorders, video systems, or other electronic entertainment equipment in homes or other venues. May perform routine maintenance.
49-2097.e: Electronic Musical Instrument Repairer, Home Theater Installer, Satellite Dish Installer, Wireless Internet Installer

49-2098.t: Security and Fire Alarm Systems Installers
49-2098.d: Install, program, maintain, and repair security and fire alarm wiring and equipment. Ensure that work is in accordance with relevant codes.
49-2098.e: Burglar Alarm Installer, Fire Alarm Installer, Home Security Alarm Installer

49-3011.d: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul aircraft engines and assemblies, such as hydraulic and pneumatic systems.
49-3011.e: Aircraft Engine Specialist, Airframe Mechanic, Flight Test Mechanic, Helicopter Engine Mechanic

49-3021.d: Repair and refinish automotive vehicle bodies and straighten vehicle frames.
49-3021.e: Auto Body Customizer, Auto Bumper Straightener, Truck Body Repairer

49-3022.d: Replace or repair broken windshields and window glass in motor vehicles.
49-3022.e: Auto Glass Mechanic, Automotive Glazier, Windshield Installer

49-3023.d: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul automotive vehicles.
49-3023.e: Auto Transmission Specialist, Automotive Brake Technician, Automotive Fuel Injection Servicer, Hybrid Car Mechanic

49-3031.t: Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists
49-3031.d: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul buses and trucks, or maintain and repair any type of diesel engines. Includes mechanics working primarily with automobile or marine diesel engines.
49-3031.e: Biodiesel Engine Specialist, Marine Diesel Technician, School Bus Mechanic, Tractor Trailer Mechanic

49-3041.t: Farm Equipment Mechanics and Service Technicians
49-3041.d: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul farm machinery and vehicles, such as tractors, harvesters, dairy equipment, and irrigation systems.
49-3041.e: Combine Mechanic, Dairy Equipment Repairer, Irrigation Equipment Mechanic

49-3042.t: Mobile Heavy Equipment Mechanics, Except Engines
49-3042.d: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul mobile mechanical, hydraulic, and pneumatic equipment, such as cranes, bulldozers, graders, and conveyors, used in construction, logging, and mining.
49-3042.e: Bulldozer Mechanic, Construction Equipment Mechanic, Forklift Mechanic

49-3043.d: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul railroad rolling stock, mine cars, or mass transit rail cars.
49-3043.e: Mine Car Mechanic, Streetcar Repairer, Subway Car Repairer, Trolley Car Overhauler

49-3051.d: Repair and adjust electrical and mechanical equipment of inboard or inboard-outboard boat engines.
49-3051.e: Certified Marine Mechanic, Outboard Motor Mechanic

49-3052.d: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul motorcycles, scooters, mopeds, dirt bikes, or similar motorized vehicles.
49-3052.e: All Terrain Vehicle Technician, Motor Scooter Mechanic, Motorcycle Service Technician

49-3053.t: Outdoor Power Equipment and Other Small Engine Mechanics
49-3053.d: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul small engines used to power lawn mowers, chain saws, recreational sporting equipment, and related equipment.
49-3053.e: Golf Cart Mechanic, Lawn Mower Repairer, Mobility Scooter Repairer, Power Saw Mechanic

49-3092.d: Diagnose, inspect, adjust, repair, or overhaul recreational vehicles including travel trailers. May specialize in maintaining gas, electrical, hydraulic, plumbing, or chassis/towing systems as well as repairing generators, appliances, and interior components. Includes workers who perform customized van conversions.

49-9011.d: Install, service, or repair automatic door mechanisms and hydraulic doors. Includes garage door mechanics.

49-9012.t: Control and Valve Installers and Repairers, Except Mechanical Door
49-9012.d: Install, repair, and maintain mechanical regulating and controlling devices, such as electric meters, gas regulators, thermostats, safety and flow valves, and other mechanical governors.
49-9012.e: Air Valve Mechanic, Gas Meter Installer, Thermostat Repairer

49-9021.t: Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers
49-9021.d: Install or repair heating, central air conditioning, HVAC, or refrigeration systems, including oil burners, hot-air furnaces, and heating stoves.
49-9021.e: Gas Furnace Installer, Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) Mechanic, Oil Burner Repairer

49-9031.d: Repair, adjust, or install all types of electric or gas household appliances, such as refrigerators, washers, dryers, and ovens.
49-9031.e: Vacuum Cleaner Repairer, Washing Machine Installer, Window Air Conditioner Installer

49-9041.d: Repair, install, adjust, or maintain industrial production and processing machinery or refinery and pipeline distribution systems. May also install, dismantle, or move machinery and heavy equipment according to plans.
49-9041.e: Boilerhouse Mechanic, Foundry Equipment Mechanic, Hydroelectric Machinery Mechanic

49-9043.d: Lubricate machinery, change parts, or perform other routine machinery maintenance.

49-9044.d: Install, dismantle, or move machinery and heavy equipment according to layout plans, blueprints, or other drawings.

49-9045.d: Build or repair equipment such as furnaces, kilns, cupolas, boilers, converters, ladles, soaking pits, and ovens, using refractory materials.

49-9051.d: Install or repair cables or wires used in electrical power or distribution systems. May erect poles and light or heavy duty transmission towers.
49-9051.e: Electric Powerline Examiner, Electric Utility Lineworker, Electrical High Tension Tester, Electrical Lineworker

49-9052.d: Install and repair telecommunications cable, including fiber optics.
49-9052.e: Cable Television Installer, FIOS Line Installer, Telephone Cable Splicer

49-9061.d: Repair and adjust cameras and photographic equipment, including commercial video and motion picture camera equipment.
49-9061.e: Aircraft Photographic Equipment Repairer, Camera Repairer, Photographic Equipment Technician

49-9062.d: Test, adjust, or repair biomedical or electromedical equipment.
49-9062.e: Biomedical Equipment Technician, Radiology Equipment Servicer, Surgical Instrument Mechanic

49-9063.d: Repair percussion, stringed, reed, or wind instruments. May specialize in one area, such as piano tuning. Excludes "Audiovisual Equipment Installers and Repairers"" (49-2097) who repair electrical and electronic musical instrument
49-9063.e: Brass and Wind Instrument Repairer, Piano Tuner, Violin Repairer

49-9064.d: Repair, clean, and adjust mechanisms of timing instruments, such as watches and clocks. Includes watchmakers, watch technicians, and mechanical timepiece repairers. Excludes ""Timing Device Assemblers and Adjusters" (51-2061
49-9064.e: Antique Clock Repairer, Clock Repair Technician, Horologist

49-9069.t: Precision Instrument and Equipment Repairers, All Other
49-9069.d: All precision instrument and equipment repairers not listed separately.

49-9071.d: Perform work involving the skills of two or more maintenance or craft occupations to keep machines, mechanical equipment, or the structure of a building in repair. Duties may involve pipe fitting; HVAC maintenance; insulating; welding; machining; carpentry; repairing electrical or mechanical equipment; installing, aligning, and balancing new equipment; and repairing buildings, floors, or stairs.
49-9071.e: Building Maintenance Mechanic, Facilities Maintenance Worker, General Maintenance Worker

49-9081.d: Inspect, diagnose, adjust, or repair wind turbines. Perform maintenance on wind turbine equipment including resolving electrical, mechanical, and hydraulic malfunctions.
49-9081.e: Wind Energy Technician, Wind Turbine Mechanic

49-9091.t: Coin, Vending, and Amusement Machine Servicers and Repairers
49-9091.d: Install, service, adjust, or repair coin, vending, or amusement machines including video games, juke boxes, pinball machines, or slot machines.
49-9091.e: Arcade Games Mechanic, Parking Meter Collector, Slot Machine Mechanic, Vending Machine Filler

49-9092.d: Work below surface of water, using surface-supplied air or scuba equipment to inspect, repair, remove, or install equipment and structures. May use a variety of power and hand tools, such as drills, sledgehammers, torches, and welding equipment. May conduct tests or experiments, rig explosives, or photograph structures or marine life.
49-9092.e: Marine Diver, Salvage Diver, Scuba Diver, Underwater Welder

49-9094.d: Repair and open locks, make keys, change locks and safe combinations, and install and repair safes.
49-9094.e: Key Maker, Safe and Vault Installer, Safe and Vault Mechanic

49-9095.t: Manufactured Building and Mobile Home Installers
49-9095.d: Move or install mobile homes or prefabricated buildings.
49-9095.e: Housetrailer Servicer, Mobile Home Mechanic, Mobile Home Servicer

49-9096.d: Set up or repair rigging for construction projects, manufacturing plants, logging yards, ships and shipyards, or for the entertainment industry.
49-9096.e: Acrobatic Rigger, Crane Rigger, Yard Rigger

49-9097.d: Install, inspect, test, maintain, or repair electric gate crossings, signals, signal equipment, track switches, section lines, or intercommunications systems within a railroad system.
49-9097.e: Light Rail Signal Technician, Rail Signal Mechanic, Third Rail Installer

49-9098.d: Help installation, maintenance, and repair workers in maintenance, parts replacement, and repair of vehicles, industrial machinery, and electrical and electronic equipment. Perform duties such as furnishing tools, materials, and supplies to other workers; cleaning work area, machines, and tools; and holding materials or tools for other workers.
49-9098.e: Automobile Body Repairer Helper, Locksmith Helper, Motorboat Mechanic Helper

49-9099.t: Installation, Maintenance, and Repair Workers, All Other
49-9099.d: All installation, maintenance, and repair workers not listed separately.
49-9099.e: Bowling Alley Mechanic, Fabric Awning Repairer, Fire Extinguisher Installer, Gasoline Pump Installer, Gunsmith, Parachute Repairer, Sail Repairer

51-1011.t: First-Line Supervisors of Production and Operating Workers
51-1011.d: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of production and operating workers, such as inspectors, precision workers, machine setters and operators, assemblers, fabricators, and plant and system operators.
51-1011.e: Assembly Line Supervisor, Machinist Supervisor, Printing Worker Supervisor

51-2011.t: Aircraft Structure, Surfaces, Rigging, and Systems Assemblers
51-2011.d: Assemble, fit, fasten, and install parts of airplanes, space vehicles, or missiles, such as tails, wings, fuselage, bulkheads, stabilizers, landing gear, rigging and control equipment, or heating and ventilating systems.
51-2011.e: Aircraft De-Icer Installer, Aircraft Fuselage Framer, Aircraft Riveter

51-2021.d: Wind wire coils used in electrical components, such as resistors and transformers, and in electrical equipment and instruments, such as field cores, bobbins, armature cores, electrical motors, generators, and control equipment.
51-2021.e: Coil Builder, Motor Winder, Wire Coiler

51-2022.d: Assemble or modify electrical or electronic equipment, such as computers, test equipment telemetering systems, electric motors, and batteries.
51-2022.e: Anode Builder, Battery Builder, Circuit Board Assembler, Electric Motor Controls Assembler

51-2023.d: Assemble or modify electromechanical equipment or devices, such as servomechanisms, gyros, dynamometers, magnetic drums, tape drives, brakes, control linkage, actuators, and appliances.
51-2023.e: Programmable Logic Controller Assembler, Synchronous Motor Assembler, Vacuum Cleaner Assembler, Vending Machine Assembler

51-2031.d: Construct, assemble, or rebuild machines, such as engines, turbines, and similar equipment used in such industries as construction, extraction, textiles, and paper manufacturing.
51-2031.e: Gas Turbine Assembler, Machine Builder, Steam Turbine Assembler

51-2041.d: Fabricate, position, align, and fit parts of structural metal products. Shipfitters are included in "Layout Workers, Metal and Plastic" (51-4192).
51-2041.e: Mill Beam Fitter, Protector Plate Attacher

51-2051.d: Laminate layers of fiberglass on molds to form boat decks and hulls, bodies for golf carts, automobiles, or other products.
51-2051.e: Fiberglass Boat Builder, Fiberglass Ski Maker

51-2061.d: Perform precision assembling or adjusting, within narrow tolerances, of timing devices such as digital clocks or timing devices with electrical or electronic components. Watchmakers are included in "Watch and Clock Repairers" (49-9064).
51-2061.e: Digital Watch Assembler, Electrical Timing Device Adjuster, Marine Chronometer Assembler

51-2092.d: Work as part of a team having responsibility for assembling an entire product or component of a product. Team assemblers can perform all tasks conducted by the team in the assembly process and rotate through all or most of them, rather than being assigned to a specific task on a permanent basis. May participate in making management decisions affecting the work. Includes team leaders who work as part of the team. Assemblers who continuously perform the same task are classified elsewhere in 51-2000.
51-2092.e: Lead Team Assembler, Team Assembly Line Machine Operator, Team Automobile Assembler

51-2099.d: All assemblers and fabricators not listed separately.
51-2099.e: Air Bag Builder, Crate Builder, Doll Maker

51-3011.d: Mix and bake ingredients to produce breads, rolls, cookies, cakes, pies, pastries, or other baked goods. Pastry chefs in restaurants and hotels are included with "Chefs and Head Cooks" (35-1011).
51-3011.e: Bagel Maker, Bread Baker, Pastry Finisher

51-3021.d: Cut, trim, or prepare consumer-sized portions of meat for use or sale in retail establishments.
51-3021.e: Butcher Apprentice, Kosher Butcher, Meat Carver, Meat Counter Worker

51-3022.t: Meat, Poultry, and Fish Cutters and Trimmers
51-3022.d: Use hands or hand tools to perform routine cutting and trimming of meat, poultry, and seafood.
51-3022.e: Fish Filleter, Oyster Shucker, Poultry Eviscerator, Shrimp Picker

51-3023.d: Perform nonroutine or precision functions involving the preparation of large portions of meat. Work may include specialized slaughtering tasks, cutting standard or premium cuts of meat for marketing, making sausage, or wrapping meats. Work typically occurs in slaughtering, meat packing, or wholesale establishments.
51-3023.e: Halal Meat Packer, Poultry Slaughterer, Shochet

51-3091.t: Food and Tobacco Roasting, Baking, and Drying Machine Operators and Tenders
51-3091.d: Operate or tend food or tobacco roasting, baking, or drying equipment, including hearth ovens, kiln driers, roasters, char kilns, and vacuum drying equipment.
51-3091.e: Coffee Roaster, Fish Smoker, Meat Curer, Smokehouse Worker

51-3092.d: Set up and operate equipment that mixes or blends ingredients used in the manufacturing of food products. Includes candy makers and cheese makers.
51-3092.e: Frozen Yogurt Maker, Honey Blender, Peanut Butter Maker

51-3093.t: Food Cooking Machine Operators and Tenders
51-3093.d: Operate or tend cooking equipment, such as steam cooking vats, deep fry cookers, pressure cookers, kettles, and boilers, to prepare food products.
51-3093.e: Doughnut Machine Operator, Dumpling Machine Operator, Potato Chip Frier

51-3099.d: All food processing workers not listed separately
51-3099.e: Olive Pitter, Poultry Hanger, Yeast Maker

51-4021.t: Extruding and Drawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4021.d: Set up, operate, or tend machines to extrude or draw thermoplastic or metal materials into tubes, rods, hoses, wire, bars, or structural shapes.

51-4022.t: Forging Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4022.d: Set up, operate, or tend forging machines to taper, shape, or form metal or plastic parts.
51-4022.e: Cold Header Operator, Forging Roll Operator, Spike Machine Operator, Swager Operator

51-4023.t: Rolling Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4023.d: Set up, operate, or tend machines to roll steel or plastic forming bends, beads, knurls, rolls, or plate, or to flatten, temper, or reduce gauge of material.
51-4023.e: Brass Roller, Forming Roll Operator, Plastic Straightening Roll Operator, Steel Roller

51-4031.t: Cutting, Punching, and Press Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4031.d: Set up, operate, or tend machines to saw, cut, shear, slit, punch, crimp, notch, bend, or straighten metal or plastic material.
51-4031.e: Crimping Machine Operator for Metal, Metal Punch Press Operator, Metal Slitter

51-4032.t: Drilling and Boring Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4032.d: Set up, operate, or tend drilling machines to drill, bore, ream, mill, or countersink metal or plastic work pieces.
51-4032.e: Boring Mill Operator for Metal, Drill Press Operator for Metal, Radial Drill Press Operator for Plastic

51-4033.t: Grinding, Lapping, Polishing, and Buffing Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4033.d: Set up, operate, or tend grinding and related tools that remove excess material or burrs from surfaces, sharpen edges or corners, or buff, hone, or polish metal or plastic work pieces.
51-4033.e: Aluminum Polisher, Jewel Bearing Facer, Metal Grinder, Tool Polishing Machine Operator

51-4034.t: Lathe and Turning Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4034.d: Set up, operate, or tend lathe and turning machines to turn, bore, thread, form, or face metal or plastic materials, such as wire, rod, or bar stock.
51-4034.e: Engine Lathe Operator, Gear Cutter, Screw Machine Operator

51-4035.t: Milling and Planing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4035.d: Set up, operate, or tend milling or planing machines to mill, plane, shape, groove, or profile metal or plastic work pieces.
51-4035.e: Metal Milling Machine Operator, Plastic Thread Milling Machine Setup Operator

51-4041.d: Set up and operate a variety of machine tools to produce precision parts and instruments out of metal. Includes precision instrument makers who fabricate, modify, or repair mechanical instruments. May also fabricate and modify parts to make or repair machine tools or maintain industrial machines, applying knowledge of mechanics, mathematics, metal properties, layout, and machining procedures. Machinists who primarily program or operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment are classified in "Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers" (51-9160).
51-4041.e: Automotive Machinist, Gear Machinist, Production Machinist

51-4051.d: Operate or tend furnaces, such as gas, oil, coal, electric-arc or electric induction, open-hearth, or oxygen furnaces, to melt and refine metal before casting or to produce specified types of steel.
51-4051.e: Electric Arc Furnace Operator, Smelter Operator

51-4052.d: Operate hand-controlled mechanisms to pour and regulate the flow of molten metal into molds to produce castings or ingots.
51-4052.e: Ingot Caster, Molten Iron Pourer, Steel Pourer

51-4061.d: Set up and operate machines, such as lathes, milling and engraving machines, and jig borers to make working models of metal or plastic objects. Includes template makers.
51-4061.e: Metal Mockup Maker, Plastic Jig and Fixture Builder

51-4062.d: Lay out, machine, fit, and assemble castings and parts to metal or plastic foundry patterns, core boxes, or match plates.

51-4071.d: Make or form wax or sand cores or molds used in the production of metal castings in foundries.
51-4071.e: Airset Caster, Green Sand Molder, Wax Pattern Coater

51-4072.t: Molding, Coremaking, and Casting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4072.d: Set up, operate, or tend metal or plastic molding, casting, or coremaking machines to mold or cast metal or thermoplastic parts or products.
51-4072.e: Aluminum Molding Machine Operator, Blow Mold Operator, Plastic Cup Fabricating Machine Operator

51-4081.t: Multiple Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4081.d: Set up, operate, or tend more than one type of cutting or forming machine tool or robot.
51-4081.e: Combination Machine Tool Operator, Multi-operation Forming Machine Setter

51-4111.d: Analyze specifications, lay out metal stock, set up and operate machine tools, and fit and assemble parts to make and repair dies, cutting tools, jigs, fixtures, gauges, and machinists' hand tools.
51-4111.e: Jig Bore Tool Maker, Metal Die Finisher, Metal Gauge Maker

51-4121.d: Use hand-welding, flame-cutting, hand-soldering, or brazing equipment to weld or join metal components or to fill holes, indentations, or seams of fabricated metal products.
51-4121.e: Arc Welder, Cutting Torch Operator, Pipe Welder, Silver Solderer

51-4122.t: Welding, Soldering, and Brazing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
51-4122.d: Set up, operate, or tend welding, soldering, or brazing machines or robots that weld, braze, solder, or heat treat metal products, components, or assemblies. Includes workers who operate laser cutters or laser-beam machines.
51-4122.e: Electron Beam Welder Setter, Ultrasonic Welding Machine Operator

51-4191.t: Heat Treating Equipment Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4191.d: Set up, operate, or tend heating equipment, such as heat-treating furnaces, flame-hardening machines, induction machines, soaking pits, or vacuum equipment to temper, harden, anneal, or heat treat metal or plastic objects.
51-4191.e: Annealing Furnace Operator, Induction Machine Setter, Wire Temperer

51-4192.d: Lay out reference points and dimensions on metal or plastic stock or workpieces, such as sheets, plates, tubes, structural shapes, castings, or machine parts, for further processing. Includes shipfitters.

51-4193.t: Plating Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
51-4193.d: Set up, operate, or tend plating machines to coat metal or plastic products with chromium, zinc, copper, cadmium, nickel, or other metal to protect or decorate surfaces. Typically, the product being coated is immersed in molten metal or an electrolytic solution.

51-4194.d: Perform precision smoothing, sharpening, polishing, or grinding of metal objects.

51-4199.t: Metal Workers and Plastic Workers, All Other
51-4199.d: All metal workers and plastic workers not listed separately.
51-4199.e: Electrical Discharge Machine Setup Operator, Metal Rivet Machine Operator, Tin Recovery Worker

51-5111.d: Format and proof text and images submitted by designers and clients into finished pages that can be printed. Includes digital and photo typesetting. May produce printing plates.
51-5111.e: Digital Proofing and Platemaker, Photoengraver, Plate Mounter

51-5112.d: Set up and operate digital, letterpress, lithographic, flexographic, gravure, or other printing machines. Includes short-run offset printing presses.
51-5112.e: Gravure Press Operator, Offset Press Operator, Web Press Operator

51-5113.d: Bind books and other publications or finish printed products by hand or machine. May set up binding and finishing machines.

51-6011.d: Operate or tend washing or dry-cleaning machines to wash or dry-clean industrial or household articles, such as cloth garments, suede, leather, furs, blankets, draperies, linens, rugs, and carpets. Includes spotters and dyers of these articles.
51-6011.e: Laundry Attendant, Laundry Equipment Operator, Laundry Sorter

51-6021.t: Pressers, Textile, Garment, and Related Materials
51-6021.d: Press or shape articles by hand or machine.
51-6021.e: Clothes Ironer, Pants Presser, Wool Presser

51-6031.d: Operate or tend sewing machines to join, reinforce, decorate, or perform related sewing operations in the manufacture of garment or nongarment products.
51-6031.e: Blind Stitch Machine Operator, Button Sewing Machine Operator, Custom T-Shirt Embroidery Machine Operator

51-6041.t: Shoe and Leather Workers and Repairers
51-6041.d: Construct, decorate, or repair leather and leather-like products, such as luggage, shoes, and saddles. May use hand tools.
51-6041.e: Cobbler, Saddle Maker, Shoe Repairer, Shoemaker

51-6042.d: Operate or tend a variety of machines to join, decorate, reinforce, or finish shoes and shoe parts.
51-6042.e: Arch Cushion Press Operator, Lasting Machine Operator, Rasper Machine Operator

51-6051.d: Sew, join, reinforce, or finish, usually with needle and thread, a variety of manufactured items. Includes weavers and stitchers.

51-6052.d: Design, make, alter, repair, or fit garments.
51-6052.e: Alterations Tailor, Coat Maker, Vest Maker

51-6061.t: Textile Bleaching and Dyeing Machine Operators and Tenders
51-6061.d: Operate or tend machines to bleach, shrink, wash, dye, or finish textiles or synthetic or glass fibers.
51-6061.e: Cloth Dyer, Rug Dyer, Skein Yarn Dyer

51-6062.t: Textile Cutting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
51-6062.d: Set up, operate, or tend machines that cut textiles.
51-6062.e: Canvas Cutter, Industrial Fabric Cutter, Welt Trimming Machine Operator

51-6063.t: Textile Knitting and Weaving Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
51-6063.d: Set up, operate, or tend machines that knit, loop, weave, or draw in textiles.
51-6063.e: Crochet Machine Operator, Jacquard Loom Weaver, Looping Machine Operator

51-6064.t: Textile Winding, Twisting, and Drawing Out Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
51-6064.d: Set up, operate, or tend machines that wind or twist textiles; or draw out and combine sliver, such as wool, hemp, or synthetic fibers. Includes slubber machine and drawing frame operators.
51-6064.e: Rope Machine Setter, Silk Winding Machine Operator

51-6091.t: Extruding and Forming Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Synthetic and Glass Fibers
51-6091.d: Set up, operate, or tend machines that extrude and form continuous filaments from synthetic materials, such as liquid polymer, rayon, and fiberglass.
51-6091.e: Fiber Machine Tender, Synthetic Filament Extruder

51-6092.d: Draw and construct sets of precision master fabric patterns or layouts. May also mark and cut fabrics and apparel.
51-6092.e: Clothing Patternmaker, Embroidery Patternmaker, Fabric Pattern Grader

51-6093.d: Make, repair, or replace upholstery for household furniture or transportation vehicles.

51-6099.t: Textile, Apparel, and Furnishings Workers, All Other
51-6099.d: All textile, apparel, and furnishings workers not listed separately.
51-6099.e: Apparel Embroidery Digitizer, Feltmaker, Hat Blocking Machine Operator

51-7011.d: Cut, shape, and assemble wooden articles or set up and operate a variety of woodworking machines, such as power saws, jointers, and mortisers to surface, cut, or shape lumber or to fabricate parts for wood products.
51-7011.e: Cabinet Builder, Marquetry Worker, Wood Furniture Assembler

51-7021.d: Shape, finish, and refinish damaged, worn, or used furniture or new high-grade furniture to specified color or finish.
51-7021.e: Furniture Sander, Piano Refinisher, Wood Cabinet Finisher

51-7031.d: Construct full-size and scale wooden precision models of products. Includes wood jig builders and loft workers.

51-7032.d: Plan, lay out, and construct wooden unit or sectional patterns used in forming sand molds for castings.

51-7041.t: Sawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Wood
51-7041.d: Set up, operate, or tend wood sawing machines. May operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment. Includes lead sawyers. Workers who primarily program or operate CNC equipment are classified in "Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers" (51-9160).
51-7041.e: Buzzsaw Operator, Circle Saw Operator, Rip Saw Operator, Trim Saw Operator

51-7042.t: Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Except Sawing
51-7042.d: Set up, operate, or tend woodworking machines, such as drill presses, lathes, shapers, routers, sanders, planers, and wood nailing machines. May operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment. Workers who primarily program or operate CNC equipment are classified in "Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers" (51-9160).
51-7042.e: Wood Dowel Machine Operator, Wood Lathe Operator, Wood Planer

51-7099.e: Pole Framer, Wood Carver, Wood Casket Assembler

51-8011.d: Operate or control nuclear reactors. Move control rods, start and stop equipment, monitor and adjust controls, and record data in logs. Implement emergency procedures when needed. May respond to abnormalities, determine cause, and recommend corrective action.
51-8011.e: Nuclear Control Room Operator, Nuclear Reactor Operator, Nuclear Station Operator

51-8012.d: Coordinate, regulate, or distribute electricity or steam.
51-8012.e: Steam Plant Control Room Operator, Substation Operator

51-8013.d: Control, operate, or maintain machinery to generate electric power. Includes auxiliary equipment operators.

51-8021.d: Operate or maintain stationary engines, boilers, or other mechanical equipment to provide utilities for buildings or industrial processes. Operate equipment such as steam engines, generators, motors, turbines, and steam boilers.
51-8021.e: Boiler Engineer, Boiler Room Operator, Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) Mechanic Boiler Operator

51-8031.t: Water and Wastewater Treatment Plant and System Operators
51-8031.d: Operate or control an entire process or system of machines, often through the use of control boards, to transfer or treat water or wastewater.
51-8031.e: Liquid Waste Treatment Plant Operator, Sewage Plant Operator

51-8091.d: Control or operate entire chemical processes or system of machines.
51-8091.e: Nitric Acid Plant Operator, Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Machine Operator

51-8092.d: Distribute or process gas for utility companies and others by controlling compressors to maintain specified pressures on main pipelines.

51-8093.t: Petroleum Pump System Operators, Refinery Operators, and Gaugers
51-8093.d: Operate or control petroleum refining or processing units. May specialize in controlling manifold and pumping systems, gauging or testing oil in storage tanks, or regulating the flow of oil into pipelines.
51-8093.e: Hydrotreater Operator, Oil Pipeline Operator, Oil Refiner

51-8099.t: Plant and System Operators, All Other
51-8099.d: All plant and system operators not listed separately.
51-8099.e: Asphalt Plant Operator, Concrete Batch Plant Operator, Lime Filter Operator

51-9011.d: Operate or tend equipment to control chemical changes or reactions in the processing of industrial or consumer products. Equipment used includes devulcanizers, steam-jacketed kettles, and reactor vessels.
51-9011.e: Acid Purification Equipment Operator, Chemical Process Equipment Operator

51-9012.t: Separating, Filtering, Clarifying, Precipitating, and Still Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
51-9012.d: Set up, operate, or tend continuous flow or vat-type equipment; filter presses; shaker screens; centrifuges; condenser tubes; precipitating, fermenting, or evaporating tanks; scrubbing towers; or batch stills. These machines extract, sort, or separate liquids, gases, or solids from other materials to recover a refined product. Includes dairy processing equipment operators.

51-9021.t: Crushing, Grinding, and Polishing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
51-9021.d: Set up, operate, or tend machines to crush, grind, or polish materials, such as coal, glass, grain, stone, food, or rubber.
51-9021.e: Beveling and Edging Machine Operator, Industrial Coffee Grinder, Marble and Granite Polisher, Pulverizer Operator

51-9022.d: Grind, sand, or polish, using hand tools or hand-held power tools, a variety of metal, wood, stone, clay, plastic, or glass objects. Includes chippers, buffers, and finishers.
51-9022.e: Hand Buffer, Hand Sander, Jewelry Polisher, Knife Grinder

51-9023.t: Mixing and Blending Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
51-9023.d: Set up, operate, or tend machines to mix or blend materials, such as chemicals, tobacco, liquids, color pigments, or explosive ingredients.
51-9023.e: Asphalt Blender, Clay Mixer, Ink Blender

51-9031.d: Use hand tools or hand-held power tools to cut and trim a variety of manufactured items, such as carpet, fabric, stone, glass, or rubber.

51-9032.t: Cutting and Slicing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
51-9032.d: Set up, operate, or tend machines that cut or slice materials, such as glass, stone, cork, rubber, tobacco, food, paper, or insulating material.
51-9032.e: Glass Cutting Machine Operator, Insulation Cutter, Rubber Trimmer

51-9041.t: Extruding, Forming, Pressing, and Compacting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
51-9041.d: Set up, operate, or tend machines, such as glass-forming machines, plodder machines, and tuber machines, to shape and form products such as glassware, food, rubber, soap, brick, tile, clay, wax, tobacco, or cosmetics.
51-9041.e: Brick Maker, Rubber Extrusion Operator, Sugar Presser

51-9051.t: Furnace, Kiln, Oven, Drier, and Kettle Operators and Tenders
51-9051.d: Operate or tend heating equipment other than basic metal, plastic, or food processing equipment. Includes activities such as annealing glass, drying lumber, curing rubber, removing moisture from materials, or boiling soap.
51-9051.e: Lime Kiln Operator, Lumber Kiln Operator, Rubber Curer

51-9061.t: Inspectors, Testers, Sorters, Samplers, and Weighers
51-9061.d: Inspect, test, sort, sample, or weigh nonagricultural raw materials or processed, machined, fabricated, or assembled parts or products for defects, wear, and deviations from specifications. May use precision measuring instruments and complex test equipment.
51-9061.e: Machined Parts Quality Inspector, Petroleum Sampler

51-9071.t: Jewelers and Precious Stone and Metal Workers
51-9071.d: Design, fabricate, adjust, repair, or appraise jewelry, gold, silver, other precious metals, or gems. Includes diamond polishers and gem cutters, and persons who perform precision casting and modeling of molds, casting metal in molds, or setting precious and semiprecious stones for jewelry and related products.

51-9081.d: Construct and repair full or partial dentures or dental appliances.
51-9081.e: Crown and Bridge Technician, Dental Ceramist, Orthodontic Technician

51-9082.d: Construct, maintain, or repair medical supportive devices such as braces, orthotics and prosthetic devices, joints, arch supports, and other surgical and medical appliances.
51-9082.e: Brace Maker, Manufacturing Orthopedic Technologist, Orthotics Technician, Prosthetics Technician

51-9083.d: Cut, grind, and polish eyeglasses, contact lenses, or other precision optical elements. Assemble and mount lenses into frames or process other optical elements. Includes precision lens polishers or grinders, centerer-edgers, and lens mounters.
51-9083.e: Eyeglass Maker, Lens Grinder, Precision Lens Centerer and Edger

51-9111.t: Packaging and Filling Machine Operators and Tenders
51-9111.d: Operate or tend machines to prepare industrial or consumer products for storage or shipment. Includes cannery workers who pack food products.
51-9111.e: Bottle Capper, Keg Filler, Potato Chip Packaging Machine Operator

51-9123.d: Paint, coat, or decorate articles, such as furniture, glass, plateware, pottery, jewelry, toys, books, or leather. Excludes "Artists and Related Workers"" (27-1010), "Designers" (27-1020), "Photographic Process Workers and Processing Machine Operators" (51-9151), and "Etchers and Engravers" (51-9194
51-9123.e: Ceramic Painter, China Decorator, Sign Painter

51-9124.t: Coating, Painting, and Spraying Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
51-9124.d: Set up, operate, or tend spraying or rolling machines to coat or paint any of a wide variety of products, including glassware, cloth, ceramics, metal, plastic, paper, or wood, with lacquer, silver, copper, rubber, varnish, glaze, enamel, oil, or rust-proofing materials. Includes painters of transportation vehicles such as painters in auto body repair facilities.
51-9124.e: Auto Painter, Electrostatic Paint Operator, Lacquer Spray Booth Operator, Railroad Car Painter

51-9141.d: Perform any or all of the following functions in the manufacture of electronic semiconductors: load semiconductor material into furnace; saw formed ingots into segments; load individual segment into crystal growing chamber and monitor controls; locate crystal axis in ingot using x-ray equipment and saw ingots into wafers; and clean, polish, and load wafers into series of special purpose furnaces, chemical baths, and equipment used to form circuitry and change conductive properties.
51-9141.e: Electronic Semiconductor Processor, Semiconductor Assembler, Wafer Fabricator

51-9151.t: Photographic Process Workers and Processing Machine Operators
51-9151.d: Perform work involved in developing and processing photographic images from film or digital media. May perform precision tasks such as editing photographic negatives and prints.
51-9151.e: Digital Photo Printer, Photo Lab Specialist, Photo Retoucher

51-9161.d: Operate computer-controlled tools, machines, or robots to machine or process parts, tools, or other work pieces made of metal, plastic, wood, stone, or other materials. May also set up and maintain equipment.
51-9161.e: Computer Numerically Controlled (CNC) Machinist, Computer Numerically Controlled (CNC) Milling Machine Operator, Computer Numerically Controlled (CNC) Shot Peening Operator, Jig Boring Machine Operator, Welding Robot Operator

51-9162.d: Develop programs to control machining or processing of materials by automatic machine tools, equipment, or systems. May also set up, operate, or maintain equipment.
51-9162.e: Computer Numerically Controlled (CNC) Programmer, Numerical Control Programmer, Numerical Tool Programmer

51-9191.t: Adhesive Bonding Machine Operators and Tenders
51-9191.d: Operate or tend bonding machines that use adhesives to join items for further processing or to form a completed product. Processes include joining veneer sheets into plywood; gluing paper; or joining rubber and rubberized fabric parts, plastic, simulated leather, or other materials.
51-9191.e: Glue Line Operator, Glue Reel Operator, Paper Gluing Operator

51-9192.t: Cleaning, Washing, and Metal Pickling Equipment Operators and Tenders
51-9192.d: Operate or tend machines to wash or clean products, such as barrels or kegs, glass items, tin plate, food, pulp, coal, plastic, or rubber, to remove impurities.
51-9192.e: Acid Dipper, Degreaser Operator, Immersion Metal Cleaner

51-9193.t: Cooling and Freezing Equipment Operators and Tenders
51-9193.d: Operate or tend equipment such as cooling and freezing units, refrigerators, batch freezers, and freezing tunnels, to cool or freeze products, food, blood plasma, and chemicals.

51-9194.d: Engrave or etch metal, wood, rubber, or other materials. Includes such workers as etcher-circuit processors, pantograph engravers, and silk screen etchers. Photoengravers are included in "Prepress Technicians and Workers" (51-5111).

51-9195.t: Molders, Shapers, and Casters, Except Metal and Plastic
51-9195.d: Mold, shape, form, cast, or carve products such as food products, figurines, tile, pipes, and candles consisting of clay, glass, plaster, concrete, stone, or combinations of materials.
51-9195.e: Cigar Roller, Glass Blower, Neon Tube Bender

51-9196.t: Paper Goods Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
51-9196.d: Set up, operate, or tend paper goods machines that perform a variety of functions, such as converting, sawing, corrugating, banding, wrapping, boxing, stitching, forming, or sealing paper or paperboard sheets into products.
51-9196.e: Box Fabricator, Carton Making Machine Operator, Corrugator Operator

51-9197.e: Auto Tire Recapper, Retreader, Tire Molder

51-9198.d: Help production workers by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include supplying or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Apprentice workers are classified in the appropriate production occupations (51-0000).
51-9198.e: Blending Tank Helper, Commercial Baker Helper, Welder Helper

51-9199.d: All production workers not listed separately.

53-1041.d: Supervise and coordinate the activities of ground crew in the loading, unloading, securing, and staging of aircraft cargo or baggage. May determine the quantity and orientation of cargo and compute aircraft center of gravity. May accompany aircraft as member of flight crew and monitor and handle cargo in flight, and assist and brief passengers on safety and emergency procedures. Includes loadmasters.
53-1041.e: Air Cargo Ground Crew Supervisor, Air Cargo Ground Operations Supervisor, Airport Ramp Supervisor

53-1042.t: First-Line Supervisors of Helpers, Laborers, and Material Movers, Hand
53-1042.d: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of helpers, laborers, or material movers, hand.
53-1042.e: Material Handling Crew Supervisor, Warehouse Supervisor

53-1043.t: First-Line Supervisors of Material-Moving Machine and Vehicle Operators
53-1043.d: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of material-moving machine and vehicle operators and helpers.
53-1043.e: Crane Crew Supervisor, Truck Driver Supervisor

53-1044.d: Supervise and coordinate activities of passenger attendants. Includes supervisors of "Flight Attendants" (53-2031).
53-1044.e: Chief Ship Steward, Flight Service Manager

53-1049.t: First-Line Supervisors of Transportation Workers, All Other
53-1049.d: All first-line supervisors of transportation workers not listed separately.

53-2011.t: Airline Pilots, Copilots, and Flight Engineers
53-2011.d: Pilot and navigate the flight of fixed-wing aircraft, usually on scheduled air carrier routes, for the transport of passengers and cargo. Requires Federal Air Transport certificate and rating for specific aircraft type used. Includes regional, national, and international airline pilots and flight instructors of airline pilots.
53-2011.e: Airline Captain, Airline Pilot In Command, Charter Pilot (Air Transport Pilot Certificate Required), Charter Pilot (Airline)

53-2012.d: Pilot and navigate the flight of fixed-wing aircraft on nonscheduled air carrier routes, or helicopters. Requires Commercial Pilot certificate. Includes charter pilots with similar certification, and air ambulance and air tour pilots. Excludes "Electro-Mechanical and Mechatronics Technologists and Technicians" (17-3024).
53-2012.e: Aerial Crop Duster, Charter Pilot (Commercial Pilot Certificate Required), Flight Instructor (Commercial Pilots), Helicopter Pilot

53-2021.d: Control air traffic on and within vicinity of airport, and movement of air traffic between altitude sectors and control centers, according to established procedures and policies. Authorize, regulate, and control commercial airline flights according to government or company regulations to expedite and ensure flight safety.
53-2021.e: Air Traffic Control Operator, Control Tower Operator, Enroute Controller

53-2022.d: Ensure the safe takeoff and landing of commercial and military aircraft. Duties include coordination between air-traffic control and maintenance personnel, dispatching, using airfield landing and navigational aids, implementing airfield safety procedures, monitoring and maintaining flight records, and applying knowledge of weather information.
53-2022.e: Aviation Operations Specialist, Flight Operations Coordinator

53-2031.d: Monitor safety of the aircraft cabin. Provide services to airline passengers, explain safety information, serve food and beverages, and respond to emergency incidents.
53-2031.e: Airline Flight Attendant, Airplane Flight Attendant

53-3011.t: Ambulance Drivers and Attendants, Except Emergency Medical Technicians
53-3011.d: Drive ambulance or assist ambulance driver in transporting sick, injured, or convalescent persons. Assist in lifting patients.

53-3031.d: Drive truck or other vehicle over established routes or within an established territory and sell or deliver goods, such as food products, including restaurant take-out items, or pick up or deliver items such as commercial laundry. May also take orders, collect payment, or stock merchandise at point of delivery.
53-3031.e: Newspaper Delivery Driver, Pizza Delivery Driver, Route Salesperson

53-3032.d: Drive a tractor-trailer combination or a truck with a capacity of at least 26,001 pounds Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW). May be required to unload truck. Requires commercial drivers' license. Includes tow truck drivers.
53-3032.e: Auto Carrier Driver, Cement Truck Driver, Dump Truck Driver, Garbage Truck Driver

53-3033.d: Drive a light vehicle, such as a truck or van, with a capacity of less than 26,001 pounds Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW), primarily to pick up merchandise or packages from a distribution center and deliver. May load and unload vehicle.
53-3033.e: Grocery Light Truck Driver, Parcel Truck Driver

53-3051.d: Drive a school bus to transport students. Ensure adherence to safety rules. May assist students in boarding or exiting.
53-3051.e: School Bus Operator, Special Education Bus Driver

53-3052.d: Drive bus or motor coach, including regular route operations, charters, and private carriage. May assist passengers with baggage. May collect fares or tickets.
53-3052.e: Motor Coach Bus Driver, Public Transit Bus Driver

53-3053.d: Drive a motor vehicle to transport passengers on a planned or scheduled basis. May collect a fare. Includes nonemergency medical transporters and hearse drivers.
53-3053.e: Airport Shuttle Driver, Courtesy Van Driver, Hotel Shuttle Driver, Nonemergency Medical Transporter

53-3054.d: Drive a motor vehicle to transport passengers on an unplanned basis and charge a fare, usually based on a meter.

53-3099.d: All motor vehicle operators not listed separately.
53-3099.e: Ice-Resurfacing Machine Operators, Motorcycle Deliverer, Street Cleaning Equipment Operator

53-4011.d: Drive electric, diesel-electric, steam, or gas-turbine-electric locomotives to transport passengers or freight. Interpret train orders, electronic or manual signals, and railroad rules and regulations.

53-4013.t: Rail Yard Engineers, Dinkey Operators, and Hostlers
53-4013.d: Drive switching or other locomotive or dinkey engines within railroad yard, industrial plant, quarry, construction project, or similar location.

53-4022.t: Railroad Brake, Signal, and Switch Operators and Locomotive Firers
53-4022.d: Operate or monitor railroad track switches or locomotive instruments. May couple or uncouple rolling stock to make up or break up trains. Watch for and relay traffic signals. May inspect couplings, air hoses, journal boxes, and hand brakes. May watch for dragging equipment or obstacles on rights-of-way.
53-4022.e: Diesel Locomotive Firer, Dinkey Engine Firer, Railway Switch Operator, Switch Coupler, Train Brake Operator

53-4031.d: Coordinate activities of switch-engine crew within railroad yard, industrial plant, or similar location. Conductors coordinate activities of train crew on passenger or freight trains. Yardmasters review train schedules and switching orders and coordinate activities of workers engaged in railroad traffic operations, such as the makeup or breakup of trains and yard switching.

53-4041.d: Operate subway or elevated suburban trains with no separate locomotive, or electric-powered streetcar, to transport passengers. May handle fares.
53-4041.e: Light Rail Transit Operator, Tram Operator, Trolley Car Operator

53-4099.d: All rail transportation workers not listed separately.
53-4099.e: Railway Equipment Operator, Retarder Operator, Transfer Table Operator

53-5011.d: Stand watch to look for obstructions in path of vessel, measure water depth, turn wheel on bridge, or use emergency equipment as directed by captain, mate, or pilot. Break out, rig, overhaul, and store cargo-handling gear, stationary rigging, and running gear. Perform a variety of maintenance tasks to preserve the painted surface of the ship and to maintain line and ship equipment. Must hold government-issued certification and tankerman certification when working aboard liquid-carrying vessels. Includes able seamen and ordinary seamen.

53-5021.t: Captains, Mates, and Pilots of Water Vessels
53-5021.d: Command or supervise operations of ships and water vessels, such as tugboats and ferryboats. Required to hold license issued by U.S. Coast Guard.
53-5021.e: Barge Captain, First Mate, Harbor Pilot, Port Captain

53-5022.d: Operate small motor-driven boats. May assist in navigational activities.
53-5022.e: Launch Operator, Speedboat Operator, Water Taxi Operator

53-5031.d: Supervise and coordinate activities of crew engaged in operating and maintaining engines, boilers, deck machinery, and electrical, sanitary, and refrigeration equipment aboard ship.
53-5031.e: Barge Engineer, Ferry Engineer, Tugboat Engineer

53-6011.d: Operate and tend bridges, canal locks, and lighthouses to permit marine passage on inland waterways, near shores, and at danger points in waterway passages. May supervise such operations. Includes drawbridge operators, lock operators, and slip bridge operators.
53-6011.e: Lighthouse Keeper, Lock and Dam Operator

53-6021.d: Park vehicles or issue tickets for customers in a parking lot or garage. May park or tend vehicles in environments such as a car dealership or rental car facility. May collect fee.

53-6031.d: Service automobiles, buses, trucks, boats, and other automotive or marine vehicles with fuel, lubricants, and accessories. Collect payment for services and supplies. May lubricate vehicle, change motor oil, refill antifreeze, or replace lights or other accessories, such as windshield wiper blades or fan belts. May repair or replace tires.
53-6031.e: Gas and Oil Servicer, Gas Pump Attendant, Service Station Attendant

53-6032.d: Service aircraft with fuel. May de-ice aircraft, refill water and cooling agents, empty sewage tanks, service air and oxygen systems, or clean and polish exterior.
53-6032.e: Aircraft De-Icer, Aircraft Refueler, Airplane Refueler

53-6041.d: Conduct field studies to determine traffic volume, speed, effectiveness of signals, adequacy of lighting, and other factors influencing traffic conditions, under direction of traffic engineer.
53-6041.e: Highway Traffic Control Technician, Traffic Signal Technician, Transportation Technician

53-6051.d: Inspect equipment or goods in connection with the safe transport of cargo or people. Includes rail transportation inspectors, such as freight inspectors, rail inspectors, and other inspectors of transportation vehicles not elsewhere classified.
53-6051.e: Aircraft Inspector, Motor Vehicle Emissions Inspector, Railroad Car Inspector

53-6061.d: Provide services to ensure the safety of passengers aboard ships, buses, trains, or within the station or terminal. Perform duties such as explaining the use of safety equipment, serving meals or beverages, or answering questions related to travel.

53-6099.d: All transportation workers not listed separately.

53-7011.d: Control or tend conveyors or conveyor systems that move materials or products to and from stockpiles, processing stations, departments, or vehicles. May control speed and routing of materials or products.
53-7011.e: Conveyor Belt Operator, Grain Elevator Operator

53-7021.d: Operate mechanical boom and cable or tower and cable equipment to lift and move materials, machines, or products in many directions.
53-7021.e: Boom Crane Operator, Cherry Picker Operator, Coal Tower Operator

53-7031.d: Operate dredge to remove sand, gravel, or other materials in order to excavate and maintain navigable channels in waterways.

53-7041.d: Operate or tend hoists or winches to lift and pull loads using power-operated cable equipment.

53-7051.d: Operate industrial trucks or tractors equipped to move materials around a warehouse, storage yard, factory, construction site, or similar location.

53-7061.d: Wash or otherwise clean vehicles, machinery, and other equipment. Use such materials as water, cleaning agents, brushes, cloths, and hoses.
53-7061.e: Aircraft Cleaner, Auto Detailer, Car Wash Attendant

53-7062.t: Laborers and Freight, Stock, and Material Movers, Hand
53-7062.d: Manually move freight, stock, luggage, or other materials, or perform other general labor. Includes all manual laborers not elsewhere classified. Excludes "Material Moving Workers" (53-7011 through 53-7199) who use power equipment.

53-7063.d: Feed materials into or remove materials from machines or equipment that is automatic or tended by other workers.

53-7064.d: Pack or package by hand a wide variety of products and materials.
53-7064.e: Egg Packer, Gift Wrapper, Grocery Store Bagger
